lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Augustine.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Augustine.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
Augustine is a CLI based chatbot that helps

Augustine uses several commands to enable users to distinguish between different tasks. For each task, the output in the terminal is as such: [%][ ] Description. Where % is either D,E or T representing deadline, event or todo respectively. The second box indicates whether the task is done or not done. This is represented by the presence of [X] in the case of done, and [ ] in the case of not done.
Specifically for the command event and deadline, dates and times in prose or in dd/mm/yyyy format are accepted by the programme. Specific outputs are given as examples in the feature section.
This command allows users to input a task that has a deadline or due date.
Okay! I've added the following task:
You now have 1 task in the list.
This command allows users to input a task that has both a duration (i.e, a start and end time/date)
Format: event DESCRIPTION /from DATE & TIME /to DATE & TIME
Okay! I've added the following task:
You now have 2 tasks in the list.
Okay! I've added the following task:
You now have 5 tasks in the list.
The todo command enables users to input tasks that have no due date or start time attatched to it.
Okay! I've added the following task:
You now have 6 tasks in the list.
The list command allows users to see the current list of tasks that the user had already input. Each task has a corresponding index which is based on the order of input (earliest to latest).
Here are the tasks in your list:
The mark command allows users to keep track of which tasks have been completed. This is indicated by the [X] in the second box. The mark command marks based on the index of the task on the list.
'mark' can only take in 1 INDEX at a time.
For example, if this is the list prior to marking:
Here are the tasks in your list:
Okay, I've marked this task as done!
Calling 'list' again will return the list with the marked tasks indicated:
Here are the tasks in your list:
The unmark command is exactly the same as mark, except that it unmarks the task instead of marking it as done. Similar to mark,
'unmark' can only take in one INDEX at a time.
The find function allows users to search for a specific keyword in their list. The output will show all the tasks to the user. The function can only take in 1 keyword at a time.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:

delete allows users to remove tasks from the list. Similar to mark and unmark, delete requires the corresponding index of the task that the user intends to remove. Just like mark and unmark, delete can only delete 1 task at a time.
If this is the list prior to deleting:
Here are the tasks in your list:
Now you have 3 tasks in the list.
Calling 'list' again will show the reflected changes:
Here are the tasks in your list:
This command is used when the user wants to exit the programme.
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
ui.showError("Error loading tasks. Starting with an empty task list.");
* Handles user input commands and performs the corresponding actions on the task list.

*
  • deadline – adds a new Deadline task with a /by date

*
  • event – adds a new Event task with /from and /to times

*
  • unmark – marks a task as not done

*
  • delete – removes a task from the list

*
  • find – searches for tasks containing a keyword
* This block also handles exceptions, including:

*
  • AugustineException – thrown for invalid input or missing arguments

*
  • NumberFormatException – thrown if a task index is not a valid integer
throw new AugustineException("Please provide a deadline in the format: deadline <description> /by <time>");
throw new AugustineException("Please provide an event in the format: event <description> /from <start> /to <end>");
Task event = new Event(description, timeParts[0].trim(), timeParts[1].trim());
throw new AugustineException("Oops! This task doesn't exist");
throw new AugustineException("Oops! This task doesn't exist");
throw new AugustineException("Please provide a valid task number");
throw new AugustineException("Oops! This task doesn't exist!");
throw new AugustineException("Please provide a valid task number");
throw new AugustineException("Oops! This task doesn't exist");
System.out.println("Now you have " + tasks.size() + " " + taskWord + " in the list.");
throw new AugustineException("Please provide a valid task number!");
throw new AugustineException("Please provide a keyword to search for");
throw new AugustineException("No tasks found with the keyword you searched for");
throw new AugustineException("I don't understand that command. Try: todo, deadline, event, list, mark, unmark, delete, bye");
* Parses a single line from the data file (data.txt) and converts it into a Task object
* that the program can use. The line is expected to follow this format:
* The 'done' field should be "1" if the task is completed, otherwise "0".
* @return A Task object (Todo, Deadline, or Event) reconstructed from the line.
* Converts a Task object into a string formatted for storage in the data file (data.txt).
* The output format depends on the task type:
* The 'done' field will be "1" if the task is marked as completed, otherwise "0".
* This format matches the expected input for {@link #parseTaskFromFile(String)},
* enabling seamless serialization and deserialization of tasks.
* This class represents a task with a deadline.
* A deadline has a task description followed by a date / time
private final String byString; // original input
private final LocalDateTime by; // parsed datetime if possible
private static final DateTimeFormatter INPUT_FORMAT = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("d/M/yyyy HHmm");
private static final DateTimeFormatter OUTPUT_FORMAT = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy HH:mm");

* An event has a task description followed by the duration in the form of /from /to

* Handles reading and writing tasks to a file.
* The Storage class is responsible for persisting the task list
* between sessions, so that the user’s tasks are not lost
* Creates a Storage object to manage saving and loading tasks
* @param filePath The path to the file used for storing tasks.
* If the file does not exist, it will be created and
* an empty task list will be returned.
* returns a list of tasks loaded from the file.
* throws AugustineException If there is an error reading the file.

* Represents a generic task. A task has a description and can be marked as done or not done.
* Specific task subclasses such as todo, event, deadline extend this class to add more details.
* Provides an array of Task objects. Provides methods to add, delete, retrive and display tasks.
*Returns a string representation of the task list,
* where each task is numbered starting from 1.
* This class handles all user interaction.
* It is responsible for showing messages to the user
* and reading inputs from the user
